question: What is the grace period for premium payments?
answer: The grace period for premium payments is 30 days from the due date.

question: What is the coverage amount?
answer: The coverage amount is up to Rs. 5 lakhs per family.

question: What are the exclusions?
answer: Exclusions include pre-existing conditions and cosmetic treatments.

question: How to file a claim?
answer: Claims can be filed online through our portal or by calling customer service.

question: Does this policy cover maternity expenses, and what are the conditions?
answer: Yes, the policy covers maternity expenses, including medical treatment expenses traceable to childbirth (including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections incurred during Hospitalization) and expenses towards lawful medical termination of pregnancy during the Policy Period. The female Insured Person should have been continuously covered for at least 24 months before availing this benefit. The New Born Baby shall be automatically covered from birth under the Sum Insured available to the mother during the corresponding Policy Period, for up to 3 months of age. [Context 3.1.14]

question: How does the policy define a 'Hospital'?
answer: A hospital is defined as any institution established for in-patient care and day care treatment of disease/ injuries and which has been registered as a hospital with the local authorities under the Clinical Establishments (Registration and Regulation) Act, 2010 or under the enactments specified under Schedule of Section 56(1) of the said Act, OR complies with all minimum criteria as under: having qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock; having at least ten inpatient beds, in those towns having a population of less than ten lacs and fifteen  inpatient beds in all other places; having qualified medical practitioner (s) in charge round the clock; having a fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out; maintaining daily records of patients and shall make these accessible to the Company’s authorized personnel. [Context 2.22]

question: What is the grace period for premium payment under the National Parivar Mediclaim Plus Policy?
answer: The grace period for premium payment under the National Parivar Mediclaim Plus Policy is thirty days.

answer: The grace period for premium payment under the National Parivar Mediclaim Plus Policy is thirty days.

question: What is the grace period for premium payment under the National Parivar Mediclaim Plus Policy?
answer: The grace period for payment of the premium shall be thirty days.

question: What is the waiting period for pre-existing diseases (PED) to be covered?
answer: Expenses related to the treatment of a Pre-Existing Disease (PED) and its direct complications shall be excluded until the expiry of thirty-six (36) months of continuous coverage after the date of inception of the first policy with us.

question: What is the extent of coverage for AYUSH treatments?
answer: The company shall indemnify Medical Expenses incurred for Inpatient Care treatment under Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha and Homeopathy systems of medicines during each Policy Period up to the limit of Sum Insured as specified in the Policy Schedule in any AYUSH Hospital.

question: Are there any sub-limits on room rent and ICU charges for Plan A?
answer: Yes, for Plan A, room charges are payable up to 1% of the Sum Insured or actual, whichever is lower, and ICU charges are payable up to 2% of the Sum Insured or actual, whichever is lower, per day per insured person. However, the limit shall not apply if the treatment is undergone for a listed procedure in a Preferred Provider Network (PPN) as a package.

question: I have done an IVF for Rs 56,000. Is it covered?
answer: Expenses related to sterility and infertility are excluded. This includes Assisted Reproduction services including artificial insemination and advanced reproductive technologies such as IVF, ZIFT, GIFT, ICSI.

question: I did a cataract treatment of Rs 100,000. Will you settle the full Rs 100,000?
answer: The policy will indemnify medical expenses incurred for the treatment of Cataract, subject to a limit of 25% of Sum Insured or INR 40,000 per eye, whichever is lower, per each eye in one Policy Period. Information not available on your total sum insured.

question: Give me a list of documents to be uploaded for hospitalization for heart surgery.
answer: The document lists the following documents to be submitted for reimbursement claims:  i. Duly completed claim form ii. Photo Identity proof of the patient iii. Medical practitioner’s prescription advising admission. iv. Original bills with itemized break-up v. Payment receipts vi. Discharge summary including complete medical history of the patient along with other details. vii. Investigation/ Diagnostic test reports etc. supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner viii. OT notes or Surgeon's certificate giving details of the operation performed (for surgical cases). ix. Sticker/Invoice of the Implants, wherever applicable. x. MLR (Medico Legal Report copy if carried out and FIR (First information report) if registered, where ever applicable. xi. NEFT Details (to enable direct credit of claim amount in bank account) and cancelled cheque xii. KYC (Identity proof with Address) of the proposer, where claim liability is above Rs. 1 Lakh as per AML Guidelines xiii. Legal heir/succession certificate, wherever applicable xiv. Any other relevant document required by Company/TPA for assessment of the claim.

answer: Expenses related to the treatment of Non-infective Arthritis shall be excluded until the expiry of 24 months of continuous coverage after the date of inception of the first policy with us.

Since you have been a customer for the last 6 years, you can raise a claim for Hydrocele.

question: Is abortion covered?
answer: Expenses towards lawful medical termination of pregnancy during the policy period are covered under Maternity Expenses. However, expenses incurred in connection with voluntary medical termination of pregnancy during the first twelve weeks from the date of conception are not covered.

question: If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
answer: The document states that according to Article 22, Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases, "No person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed, as soon as may be, of the grounds for such arrest nor shall he be denied the right to consult, and to be defended by, a legal practitioner of his choice."  The legality of an arrest without a warrant depends on the specific circumstances and the laws of the jurisdiction. This document does not provide enough information to determine legality.

question: If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
answer: Based on the document, Article 15, titled "Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth," states that the State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth, or any of them.  Also, Article 16, titled "Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment," ensures equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State. It also prohibits discrimination based on religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence, or any of them, in respect of any employment or office under the State.  Information not available in document regarding whether a private employer can discriminate based on caste.

question: If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
answer: The document mentions the following:  *   Article 31A: Saving of Laws providing for acquisition of estates, etc. *   Article 300A: Persons not to be deprived of property save by authority of law.  It appears the government can acquire land for projects, but it must be done with the authority of law.  Whether you can stop it depends on the specific laws and the circumstances. This document does not provide enough information to determine if you can stop the government from taking your land.

question: If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
answer: No. According to Article 24, the prohibition of employment of children in factories, etc., states that "No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment."

question: If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
answer: Based on the document, the following article may apply to your question:  **Article 19. Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc** (1) All citizens shall have the right— (a) to freedom of speech and expression;  (2) Nothing in sub-clause (a) of clause (1) shall affect the operation of any existing law, or prevent the State from making any law, in so far as such law imposes reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right conferred by the said sub-clause in the interests of [the sovereignty and integrity of India], the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation or incitement to an offence.  This suggests that you have the right to freedom of speech and expression, but this right can be reasonably restricted by law in the interest of public order.  Information not available in document.

question: If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
answer: Article 25.1 states: "Subject to public order, morality and health and to the other provisions of this Part, all persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right freely to profess, practice and propagate religion."  Information not available in document regarding whether the government can stop someone from changing their religion.

question: If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
answer: Based on the document, the right to "Protection in respect of conviction for offences" (Article 20) and "Protection of life and personal liberty" (Article 21) are violated if police torture someone in custody.

question: If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answer: Yes, according to Article 15 (5), the State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens or for the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, specifically regarding admission to educational institutions, including private institutions, except for minority educational institutions.  If you are denied admission based solely on your religion, race, caste, language, or any of them, Article 29 (2) states that no citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on these grounds.  If you believe your rights have been violated, you can seek remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by Part III according to Article 32.

question: Describe the steps to port a prior individual policy from another insurer for a dependent parent-in-law, list documents needed for a post-hospitalization medicine claim for your child, and provide the toll-free customer service number.
answer: To port an individual health insurance policy to OICL from another insurer for a dependent parent-in-law: 1.  Apply to OICL to port the entire policy along with all family members, if any, at least 30 days before, but not earlier than 60 days from the policy renewal date, as per IRDAI guidelines. 2.  Ensure the person is currently covered and has been continuously covered without any lapses under any health insurance policy with an Indian General/Health insurer. 3.  The proposed insured person will get the accrued continuity benefits in waiting periods as per IRDAI guidelines on portability.  For a post-hospitalization medicine claim for your child, submit the following documents to the Company/TPA within 15 days from the completion of such treatment (up to 60 days or actual period, whichever is less):  *   Original bills/cash memos from the hospital(s)/chemist(s) supported by a proper prescription. *   All documents must be duly attested by the Insured Person/Claimant.  The toll-free customer service number is 1800118485.

Information not available in document regarding:  *   Whether mid-term dependent inclusion is possible for a newborn. *   The process to change communication email for the primary insured.

answer: The document states that according to Article 22, Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases, "No person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed, as soon as may be, of the grounds for such arrest nor shall he be denied the right to consult, and to be defended by, a legal practitioner of his choice."  The legality of an arrest without a warrant depends on the specific circumstances and the laws of the jurisdiction. This document does not provide enough information to determine legality.

question: If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
answer: Based on the document, Article 15, titled "Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth," states that the State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth, or any of them.  Also, Article 16, titled "Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment," ensures equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State. It also prohibits discrimination based on religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence, or any of them, in respect of any employment or office under the State.  Information not available in document regarding whether a private employer can discriminate based on caste.

question: How does Newton define 'quantity of motion' and how is it distinct from 'force'?
answer: Based on the provided document:  *   **Quantity of Motion:** Newton defines it as the measure of motion arising from the velocity and quantity of matter conjunctly. *   **Force:** Newton defines impressed force as an action exerted upon a body to change its state, whether of rest or uniform motion in a right line. This force consists in the action only and does not remain in the body when the action is over.  The key distinction is that quantity of motion is a property *of* a moving body, determined by its mass and velocity. Force, on the other hand, is an *external* action that causes a change in a body's state of motion.

question: How does Newton demonstrate that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses?
answer: Newton compares the space through which heavy bodies fall in one second of time at the surface of the earth with the space through which the moon falls, as it were, to the earth in the same time, while revolving in a circular orbit. He conjectures that if the moon is retained in her orbit by the force of gravity, the primary planets must also be carried round the sun by the like power; and, by comparing the periods of the several planets with their distances from the sun, he found that, if they were held in their courses by any power like gravity, its strength must decrease in the duplicate proportion of the increase of distance.

question: What is Newton's argument for why gravitational force must act on all masses universally?
answer: Error: Request timeout

question: How does Newton explain the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets?
answer: Based on the provided text, here's how Newton addresses the perturbation of planetary orbits:  *   **Mutual Gravitation:** Newton states that all planets mutually gravitate towards one another. *   **Disturbance of Orbits:** He acknowledges that this mutual gravitation causes disturbances in the orbits of the planets. *   **Relative Size Matters:** The text indicates that the amount of perturbation depends on the relative sizes of the bodies involved. For example, the action of Jupiter on Saturn is significant because of Jupiter's size. *   **Approximation:** Newton suggests that these perturbations can be approximated by considering the forces involved. *   **Peaceful coexistence:** Newton states that the planets are placed at different distances from the sun so that they may enjoy a degree of heat suitable to its condition and proper for its nourishment.  In essence, Newton recognizes that planets don't just orbit the sun in isolation. Their mutual gravitational interactions cause deviations from perfect elliptical orbits, leading to perturbations.

question: A claim was lodged for expenses on a prosthetic device after a hip replacement surgery. The hospital bill also includes the cost of a walker and a lumbar belt post-discharge. Which items are payable?

question: An insured's child (a dependent above 18 but under 26, unemployed and unmarried) requires dental surgery after an accident. What is the claim admissibility, considering both eligibility and dental exclusions, and what is the process for this specific scenario?

Accident Necessity: Verify that the dental surgery is necessitated due to an accident. 3.  Hospitalization Requirement: Ensure that the dental surgery requires a minimum of 24 hours of hospitalization. 4.  Claim Submission: If the above conditions are met, submit the claim with the necessary documents, including:     *   Duly completed claim form.     *   Photo ID and Age proof of the child.     *   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents.     *   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/ nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription

question: If a policyholder files a claim for inpatient psychiatric treatment, attaching as supporting documents a prescription from a general practitioner and a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist, is this sufficient? Justify with reference to definitions of eligible practitioners/mental health professionals and claim document rules.
answer: Based on the provided document, here's the answer to your question:  No, a prescription from a general practitioner and a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist may not be sufficient for a claim for inpatient psychiatric treatment.  Here's the justification:  *   **Definition of Medical Practitioner:** The policy defines a "Medical Practitioner" as someone holding a valid registration from the Medical Council of any State or Medical Council of India or Council for Indian Medicine or for Homeopathy set up by the Government of India or a State Government and is thereby entitled to practice medicine within its jurisdiction; and is acting within its scope and jurisdiction of license. *   **Definition of Mental Healthcare Professional:** The policy defines a "Mental Healthcare Professional" meansâ€” (i) a psychiatrist (ii) a professional registered with the concerned State Authority or (iii) a professional having a post-graduate degree (Ayurveda) in Mano Vigyan Avum Manas Roga or a post-graduate degree (Homoeopathy) in Psychiatry or a post-graduate degree (Unani) in Moalijat (Nafasiyatt) or a post-graduate degree (Siddha) in Sirappu Maruthuvam or (iv) a Clinical Psychologist. *   **Requirements for Claim Documents:** The policy requires an attending medical practitioner's/surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis.  While a Clinical Psychologist is listed as a Mental Healthcare Professional, the policy also requires

question: A patient receives oral chemotherapy in a network hospital and requests reimbursement for ECG electrodes and gloves used during each session. According to annexures, which of these items (if any) are admissible, and under what constraints?
answer: According to the document:  *   **ECG Electrodes:** Payable, up to 5 electrodes are required for every case visiting OT or ICU. For longer stay in ICU, may require a change and at least one set every second day is payable. *   **Gloves:** Sterilized Gloves payable / unsterilized gloves not payable.

question: A hospitalized insured person develops an infection requiring post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses 20 days after discharge. Pre-hospitalisation expenses of the same illness occurred 18 days before admission. Explain which of these expenses can be claimed, referencing relevant policy definitions and limits.
answer: Based on the provided document:  *   **Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover:** The policy covers pre-hospitalisation medical expenses incurred 30 days before hospitalisation, provided the expenses are for the same condition for which the insured person's hospitalisation was required. *   **Post-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover:** The policy covers post-hospitalisation medical expenses incurred for 60 days immediately after the insured person is discharged from the hospital, provided the expenses are for the same condition for which the insured person's hospitalisation was required.  Therefore, both the pre-hospitalisation and post-hospitalisation expenses can be claimed as they fall within the specified timeframes (30 days and 60 days, respectively) and are related to the same illness that led to hospitalisation.

question: If a dependent child turns 27 during the policy period but the premium was paid at the beginning of the coverage year, how long does their coverage continue, and when is it terminated with respect to eligibility and deletion protocols?
answer: According to section V.B.3.b.iii, children above 18 years will continue to be covered along with parents up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried/unemployed and dependent.  According to section V.B.15.B.iv, cover will end for a member or dependent when a dependent insured person ceases to be a Dependent; unless otherwise agreed specifically for continuation till end of policy period.  Therefore, if a dependent child turns 27 during the policy period, their coverage would cease at that time unless otherwise agreed specifically for continuation till the end of the policy period.

question: A procedure was conducted in a hospital where the insured opted for a single private room costing more than the allowed room rent limit. Diagnostic and specialist fees are billed separately. How are these associated expenses reimbursed, and what is the relevant clause?
answer: If the insured is admitted to a room with rates exceeding the limits mentioned in the Policy Schedule/Certificate of Insurance, the reimbursement/payment of all associated medical expenses incurred at the Hospital shall be effected in the same proportion as the admissible rate per day bears to the actual rate per day of Room Rent. This is detailed under Clause III.A.1, Note 1, which discusses the Proportionate Clause.

question: Describe the course of action if a claim is partly rejected due to lack of required documentation, the insured resubmits the documents after 10 days, and then wishes to contest a final rejection. Refer to claim timeline rules and grievance procedures.
answer: If a claim is partly rejected due to a lack of necessary documentation, the insured has 10 working days to fulfill the deficiency. The company may send a maximum of 3 reminders. If the insured resubmits the documents after 10 days and the claim is ultimately rejected, the insured can represent to the company for reconsideration within 15 days from the date of receipt of the claims decision. If still unsatisfied, the insured can contact the grievance officer or approach the Insurance Ombudsman of the respective area/region for redressal of grievance as per Insurance Ombudsman Rules 2017.

question: An insured person is hospitalized for 22 hours for a minimally invasive surgery under general anesthesia. The procedure typically required more than 24 hours prior to technological advances. Is their claim eligible? Cite the relevant category and its requirements.
answer: Yes, the claim is eligible under the Day Care Treatment Cover.  According to the document, Day Care Treatment means medical treatment, and/or surgical procedure which is:  i. undertaken under General or Local Anesthesia in a hospital/day care centre in less than 24 hours because of technological advancement, and ii. which would have otherwise required a hospitalisation of more than 24 hours. Treatment normally taken on an out-patient basis is not included in the scope of this definition.

question: When the insured is hospitalized in a town with less than 1 million population, what are the minimum infrastructure requirements for the hospital to qualify under this policy, and how are they different in metropolitan areas?
answer: According to the document, the minimum infrastructure requirements for a hospital to qualify under this policy are:  *   Qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock. *   At least 10 in-patient beds in towns having a population of less than 1,000,000 and at least 15 in-patient beds in all other places. *   Qualified medical practitioner(s) in charge round the clock. *   A fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out. *   Maintains daily records of patients and makes these accessible to the insurance company's authorized personnel.  The difference in infrastructure requirements between towns with a population of less than 1,000,000 and metropolitan areas is the number of in-patient beds: 10 versus 15, respectively.

question: A group employer wishes to add a new employee, their spouse, and sibling as insured persons mid-policy. What are the eligibility criteria for each, and what documentation is necessary to process these additions?
answer: To be eligible for coverage under the policy, the new employee must be either an employee of the policyholder where there is an employer/employee relationship OR a member of the group as defined in extant IRDAI guidelines on Group Health Insurance in case of Non-Employer-Employee policies.  The relationships which may be covered under the Policy are: *   Self *   Employee/member's legal Spouse, Life Partner (including live-in partner) *   The Employee/member's siblings shall be covered up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried/unemployed and dependent.  To add these members, the policy states: *   The Policyholder must give Us all the written information that is reasonably required to work out the premium and pay any claim/ Benefit provided under the Policy. *   You must give Us written notification specifying the details of the Insured Persons to be deleted and the details of the eligible persons proposed to be added to the Policy as Insured Persons. *   Material information to be disclosed includes every matter that the Insured Person and/or the Policyholder is aware of, or could reasonably be expected to know, that relates to questions in the proposal form and which is relevant to Us in order to accept the risk of insurance.  Additional premium on pro-rata basis applied on the risk coverage duration for the Insured Person has to be received by Us and We have to issue an endorsement confirming the addition

question: Summarize the coverage for robotic surgery for cancer, including applicable sub-limits, when done as a day care procedure vs inpatient hospitalization.
answer: For robotic surgeries, including robotic-assisted surgeries, the following limits apply per policy period:  *   For the treatment of any disease involving the Central Nervous System irrespective of etiology, or for malignancies: up to the limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance. *   For robotic surgeries for other diseases: up to the limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance.  These limits apply whether the surgery is performed as an inpatient or as part of day care treatment in a hospital.

question: If an accident necessitates air ambulance evacuation with subsequent inpatient admission, what steps must be followed for both pre-authorization and claims assessment? Discuss mandatory requirements and documentation.
answer: For air ambulance evacuation followed by inpatient admission due to an accident, the following steps and requirements apply:  1.  **Pre-authorization**:     *   The Insured Person must notify United India Insurance Company Limited (UIIC) immediately either at Our call center or in writing.     *   Emergency medical evacuations shall be pre-authorized by Us.     *   Our team of Specialists in association with the Emergency assistance service provider shall determine the medical necessity of such Emergency evacuation or repatriation post which the same will be approved.  2.  **Claims Assessment**:     *   Follow the claim process laid down under Clause VI of the Policy towards Cashless facility or reimbursement respectively in order to assess and determine the applicability of the Deductible on such claim.     *   Submit the claim to TPA with in the prescribed time limit.     *   Air ambulance ticket for registered service provider.  3.  **Mandatory Requirements and Documentation**:     *   Duly completed claim form.     *   Photo ID and Age proof.     *   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents.     *   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/ nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner.     *   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current

question: Explain how the policy treats waiting periods for a specific illness (e.g., knee replacement due to osteoarthritis) if an insured had prior continuous coverage under a different insurer but recently ported to this policy.
answer: If the insured person is continuously covered without any break as defined under the applicable norms on portability stipulated by IRDAI, then the waiting period for the specific illness would be reduced to the extent of prior coverage.

question: If a doctor prescribes an imported medication not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment, will the expense be covered? Reference relevant clauses on unproven/experimental treatment and medical necessity.
answer: The document states that expenses related to any unproven treatment, services, and supplies for or in connection with any treatment are excluded. Unproven treatments are treatments, procedures, or supplies that lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness. (Code- Excl16)  The document also states that Medically Necessary Treatment means any treatment, tests, medication, or stay in hospital or part of a stay in hospital which must conform to the professional standards widely accepted in international medical practice or by the medical community in India.  Therefore, if the imported medication is not based on established medical practice in India or lacks significant medical documentation to support its effectiveness, it would likely be considered an unproven treatment and not covered. Additionally, for the treatment to be covered, it must be deemed medically necessary.

question: A member of a non-employer group policy dies during the policy period. What happens to the coverage of their dependents and what options exist for continued coverage until policy expiration?
answer: In the event of the death of an employee, their dependents may continue to be covered until the expiry of the policy period at the option of the insured.

question: For claims involving implanted devices (e.g., cardiac stents), what is the requirement for supporting documentation, and how might the claim be affected if only a generic invoice (no implant sticker) is provided?
answer: Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries i.e. lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery is required. Information not available regarding how the claim might be affected if only a generic invoice (no implant sticker) is provided.

question: A spouse suffers a serious accident and is incapacitated, requiring prolonged home nursing after discharge. Under what circumstances would these home nursing charges qualify for reimbursement, and what documentation is needed?
answer: Home nursing charges are covered if:  1.  Arranged by the Hospital for a Qualified Nurse to visit the patient's home to give expert nursing services immediately after Hospital Treatment for as long as is required by medical necessity. 2.  Visits are for Treatment which would normally be provided in a Hospital. 3.  The Specialist who treated the patient must have recommended these services.  Documentation needed: Bills from registered nursing service provider.

question: In the case of a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, what is the procedure for claim settlement, coordination, and required documentation?
answer: In a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, the primary Insurer shall seek details of other available policies of the policyholder and shall coordinate with other Insurers to ensure settlement of the balance amount as per the policy conditions, provided a written request for same has been submitted by the Insured Person.

question: Suppose the insured's hospitalization was for evaluation and all tests and imaging were negative, leading to a decision for no treatment. Are these expenses claimable? Discuss using definitions and exclusions.
answer: Expenses related to any admission primarily for diagnostics and evaluation purposes only are excluded as per exclusion B.4.i.

question: How does the insurer treat requests to update the nominee after the sudden demise of the previous nominee and in the absence of any prior endorsement for nominee change?
answer: In the event of the policyholder's death, the document states that the company will pay the nominee as named in the Policy Schedule/Policy Certificate/Endorsement (if any). In the case where there is no subsisting nominee, payment will be made to the legal heirs or legal representatives of the policyholder whose discharge shall be treated as full and final discharge of its liability under the policy.

question: List scenarios where prostheses or medical appliances are NOT covered, even if associated with hospitalization. Use definitions and exclusions for your justification.
answer: Prostheses and medical appliances are NOT covered in the following scenarios:  1.  **Not Required Intra-operatively:** If the prostheses, corrective devices, and/or medical appliances are not required during the surgery for which the insured person was hospitalized (Specific Exclusion C.19). 2.  **Not Medically Necessary:** If an artificial device or prosthesis is not a necessary part of the treatment immediately following surgery or is not required by medical necessity (Specific Definition B.38). 3.  **Cosmetic Surgery:** Expenses for cosmetic or plastic surgery or any treatment to change appearance unless for reconstruction following an Accident, Burn(s) or Cancer or as part of medically necessary treatment to remove a direct and immediate health risk to the Insured. For this to be considered a medical necessity, it must be certified by the attending Medical Practitioner (Standard Permanent Exclusion B.8). 4.  **Unproven Treatments:** Expenses related to any unproven treatment, services and supplies for or in connection with any treatment. Unproven treatments are treatments, procedures or supplies that lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness (Standard Permanent Exclusion B.16). 5.  **External Congenital Anomaly:** External Congenital Anomaly or defects (Specific Exclusion C.4). 6.  **Treatment Received Outside India:** Treatment received outside India (Specific Exclusion C.20). 7.  **Non-Medical Expenses:** All non-medical expenses

question: If a patient receives inpatient care for mental illness from an AYUSH hospital that is not registered locally but has qualified practitioners, will expenses be reimbursed? Why or why not?
answer: Expenses will not be reimbursed. As per the definition of AYUSH Day Care Centre, the health center must be registered with the local authorities.

question: An insured requests cashless facility for hospitalization at a network provider and subsequently changes their treatment plan resulting in a higher estimate. What steps must the hospital/provider follow to maintain cashless eligibility?
answer: In the event of any change in the diagnosis, plan of Treatment, cost of Treatment during Hospitalisation to the Insured Person, the Network Provider shall obtain a fresh authorization letter from Us in accordance with the process described under clause V.4 above.

question: If a claim for pre-hospitalization expenses is submitted before the main inpatient hospitalization claim has been approved, how is this processed according to the assessment sequence outlined in the policy?
answer: The Pre-Hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover claim shall be processed only after the decision of the main Hospitalisation claim.

question: Describe the steps to port a prior individual policy from another insurer for a dependent parent-in-law, list documents needed for a post-hospitalization medicine claim for your child, and provide the toll-free customer service number.
answer: To port an individual health insurance policy to OICL from another insurer for a dependent parent-in-law: 1.  Apply to OICL to port the entire policy along with all family members, if any, at least 30 days before, but not earlier than 60 days from the policy renewal date, as per IRDAI guidelines. 2.  Ensure the person is currently covered and has been continuously covered without any lapses under any health insurance policy with an Indian General/Health insurer. 3.  The proposed insured person will get the accrued continuity benefits in waiting periods as per IRDAI guidelines on portability.  For a post-hospitalization medicine claim for your child, submit the following documents to the Company/TPA within 15 days from the completion of such treatment (up to 60 days or actual period, whichever is less):  *   Original bills/cash memos from the hospital(s)/chemist(s) supported by a proper prescription. *   All documents must be duly attested by the Insured Person/Claimant.  The toll-free customer service number is 1800118485.

question: If a spouse is set for a scheduled caesarean delivery at an out-of-town hospital not in the company's approved list, also ask if mid-term dependent inclusion is possible for a newborn, and the process to change communication email for the primary insured.
answer: Based on the document:  *   For Diamond and Platinum plans, the company shall pay the Medical Expenses incurred as an In-patient for a delivery (including caesarean section) or lawful medical termination of pregnancy during the Policy Period limited to two deliveries or terminations or either during the lifetime of the Insured Person. *   Cashless Access Services will be through the Company / TPA provided admission is in a network Hospital/ Nursing Home and is subject to pre admission authorization. *   Midterm inclusion of members is permitted under the Policy, on payment of pro-rata premium only for a newborn child from 1 day of birth or at the time of renewal of the Policy. *   Insured must inform the Company immediately in writing of any change in the address. *   Every notice or communication to be given or made under this Policy shall be delivered in writing at the address of the Policy issuing office / Third Party Administrator as shown in the Schedule.
